original_title: Sri Lanka’s proposed anti-corruption bill has failed to encourage whistleblowers – TISL
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s new anti-corruption bill has not encouraged whistleblowers against bribery and corruption, refusing a cultural shift in tackling the financial misappropriations, a top official of the local Transparency International said.
The new bill is expected to be brought to parliament and enacted by June this year.
The new bill is silent on informants who speak out against bribery and corruption in the country.
“We need a cultural shift,” Sankitha Gunaratne, the Deputy Executive Director of Transparency International Sri Lanka (TISL) told a media briefing on Tuesday.
“We need a country where public officers are transparent and the people are not afraid to speak up. We also need a country with unbiased law enforcement.
Global and local rights groups have long demanded the island nation to take a tough stance on corruption and misappropriation of public funds.

However, President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s administration has agreed with the International Monetary Fund to tackle the corruption issue and bring in Stolen Asset Recovery Law in return for a $3 billion loan.

Majority of Sri Lankans believe some key politicians including former leader Mahinda Rajapaksa’s family members had stashed money in foreign countries when they were in power. However, there have been inconclusive investigations into such allegations in the past and Rajapaksa has denied such wrong doing, analysts say.

The unprecedented economic crisis also has forced the current government to look into leakages of state revenue and the latest anti-corruption bill is expected to address many of those issues, government officials have said.

The IMF has urged Sri Lanka to reduce corruption vulnerabilities through improving fiscal transparency and public financial management, introducing a stronger anti-corruption legal framework, and conducting an in-depth governance diagnostic, supported by IMF technical assistance.

“The new bill will highlight previously neglected issues such as bribery in private corporations and sexual bribery,” Sankitha Gunaratne Deputy Executive Director of Transparency International Sri Lanka (TISL) told a media briefing on Tuesday (11).
Related – Ahead of IMF approval, Sri Lanka govt promises anti-corruption bill
The proposed new bill once enacted, along with the 21st amendment to the constitution, increases the power of the bribery commission and gives them powers to conduct investigations.

“The law on Bribery and Corruption at present has a provision on secrecy upon which even an officer who is authorized to give information to the public can be restricted by these provisions,” Gunaratne said.
“This is perhaps one of the positive aspects of the new bill.”

However, she also highlighted the proposed new bill including the possibility of new bill overruling the existing powerful Right to Information (RTI) Act and as a result, the TISL remains skeptical on how a cultural and social shift would be driven by the new bill. (Colombo/April12/2023)
